caseTitle: THEODORE ADJEI OSAE (DR.) & ORS v NUMO NORTEY ADJEIFIO & ORS
summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana case, decided on 7th May 2008, involved a civil land dispute between Dr. Theodore Adjei Osae and others (appellants) and Numo Nortey Adjefio and others (respondents) over a declaration of title and perpetual injunction concerning land in Teshie. The trial court had ruled for the appellants, but the Court of Appeal reversed the decision. The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal's judgment, dismissing the appeal. The core issue was the boundary of Teshie quarter lands apportioned in 1927–1928. The appellants failed to establish the boundaries with certainty, offering conflicting oral testimony and relying on a site plan improperly attached to pleadings, which lacked proper evidentiary value. Crucially, Exhibit 1D4—a document authored by the first appellant as Chairman of Teshie Town Council—stated that Teshie lands extended to the Akuapim Hills, contradicting his trial testimony. This prior inconsistent statement, admitted without objection, carried significant weight. The Court emphasized that to succeed in a land title action, plaintiffs must prove identity and limits of the land by positive evidence, which the appellants failed to do. The Court also affirmed that Otinshie, founded before 1927, formed part of Kle Musum quarter, with allodial title resting in the respondents, leaving the appellants with only possessory or usufructuary rights. The appeal was dismissed on all grounds.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; decision of the Court of Appeal upheld in favor of the respondents.
citations: Akufo- Addo vs. Catheline [1992]1 GLR377 SC
Godka Group of Companies vs. PS International Ltd [2001-2002] SCGLR SC 918
rationaleHighlights: Appellants failed to prove boundaries on balance of probabilities
Documentary evidence (Exhibit 1D4) favored respondents due to prior inconsistent statement
Site plan attached to pleadings lacked probative value under Order 19 r.4
Failure to call adjoining landowners weakened appellants' case
Court of Appeal correctly found Otinshie part of Kle Musum quarter
Appellants' evidence was conflicting and uncertain on key boundaries
